moves.1. e4 e5 2. a3: Mengarini's opening? Never seen before, it looks awkward, doesn't follow any opening principle, seems a lose of tempo hence White's initial advantage.
moves.8... Be7: Offering a bishop trade for the control of e-file with the queen
moves.9... Nd4: By principle this is not correct as I should have fully developed before jumping towards enemy's line
moves.10. Nxd4: The knight trade allowed for an open file that will be a central theme on this game
moves.10... exd4 11. Bf3 Re8: Taking control of the open file and threatening with a discovered check
moves.12. Be4: Closing the threat but allowing a nasty pin
moves.12... Bg5: This was a mistake, although the white bishop is pinned he could neutralize it by simply castling, then the bishop in g5 wont get any advantage.
moves.13. Qh5: Blunder!! It probably seemed a good idea to double attack Black's bishop while threatening check with Qxh7+ but this attack hasn't the necessary steam and as we'll soon see White's light bishop is lost.
moves.13... Bxd2+: I know light White's bishop is lost and has nowhere to go while is pinned. A good idea when you have material advantage is to trade pieces to simplifly, this Bishop trade was possible thanks to the check, otherwise would follow a dangerous check with Qxh7.
moves.14. Nxd2 g6: Is time to ask White's queen what's going on
moves.15. Qf3 f5: There is, Bishop is gone, but not before a desperate defence
moves.16. c4 dxc3 e.p. 17. bxc3 Nxc3: Bishop can wait. Who can deny a free lunch?
moves.19. dxe4: Interesting position, black Knight is attacked twice and look's like lost, but it has an elegant farewell that unfortunatly I didn't see it until the move was done.
moves.19... Nb5: So bad... Solution was 19...Nxe4!, then after 20. Nxe4 would follow 20... Qd5 winning back the knight offering a queen exchange
moves.20. Qb3+: Obvious. Taking advantage of my blunder.
moves.20... Kh8 21. Qxb5: Material is again equal, so the fight continues.
moves.23... Be6: Defending the diagonal, now the King should be safe.
moves.26. e5: Advancing the passed pawn, strongly defended.
moves.27. Qe2 Qxa3: Hunted! Now there are three passed pawns on the queen side but they are far away for promoting
moves.28. Ng5: The knight is taking some action attacking the bishop while thretening h7 square for a dreamed mate
moves.28... Bd5: I feel that the Bishop is still usefull and stronger than the Knight as the position is quite open.
moves.29. Qg4: White queen has no good intentions
moves.29... Qf8: Back home to defend the King
moves.30. Qd7: If the turn where for White, Qxh7 would be the end but move is for black.
moves.31. Qg4 Rd2: Taking control of the 2nd rank. Although a pawn less White has some defence chances, he should be thinking on trade Knight for Bishop, then push further his passed pawn.
moves.33. Nf3: Blunder!! He should offered a cleaner trade with Ke4, now he will lose another pawn reducing the chances if any.
moves.33... Bxf3 34. gxf3 Qxf3 35. Qc4+: Spite check. It seems better to make retreat Black's queen with Re3 then try ro advance f pawn. BTW if greedy enough for 35. Qxh6, mate in 2 would follow with 35... Qxf2+ 36.Kh1 Qxg2#
moves.35... Rf7: Threatening mate if not properly defended
moves.36. Qf1: No good, this allows three major pieces on f file with mate shortly.
